title: 111_hr2022
content: The "Kids IRA Act of 2009" or "K-IRA Act" is the short title of the Act. It establishes the Young Savers Account. The "Kids IRA Act of 2009" establishes the Young Savers Account, a type of Roth IRA for individuals under 26 years old with specific contribution limits. The contribution limits for young savers accounts under the "Kids IRA Act of 2009" are increased based on qualified contributions made by individuals for the taxable year. The "Kids IRA Act of 2009" increases contribution limits for young savers accounts based on qualified contributions made by individuals for the taxable year. Qualified young saver contributions are defined as contributions to a young savers account established on behalf of another individual, with limitations on the aggregate amount that can be contributed for any taxable year. The "Kids IRA Act of 2009" amends Section 219 of the Code to limit the aggregate amount of qualified contributions an individual can make to young savers accounts for any taxable year. The "Kids IRA Act of 2009" adds a new subsection allowing a 20% deduction for qualified young saver contributions up to $5,000, with limits based on modified adjusted gross income. The tax code specifies different dollar amounts for taxpayers based on filing status, with adjustments for inflation starting in 2010. The tax code specifies dollar amounts for taxpayers based on filing status, with adjustments for inflation starting in 2010. Any increase determined shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000. A conforming amendment is made to section 408A(c) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009.
